thread.title: Kenya: August Inflation Recedes as Food Prices Drop Marginally
thread.title_full: Kenya: August Inflation Recedes as Food Prices Drop Marginally

title: Kenya: August Inflation Recedes as Food Prices Drop Marginally
text:
East Africa: EAC Partner States Face a Decline in Economic Growth 
Vegetables recorded the highest drop, according to the data, with a kilo of carrots, spinach and tomatoes costing 4.70, 3.53 and 3.42 per cent less respectively, compared to July. A kilo of staple maize grain fell by 0.73 per cent to Sh44.85, but a two-kilo sifted maize flour retailed 1.89 per cent higher to Sh115.13 on average, suggesting the lowpriced maize grain is yet to reach the millers. Kenyans however paid higher household rental and utility bills in August than in July with the index for housing, electricity, water and cooking gas rising 0.26 per cent month on month on impact of weakening shilling against the dollar. 
The biggest price hike was experienced in transportation costs whose index jumped 1.42 per cent month-on-month on account of increases in fares and petrol prices, the KNBS said. "I am surprised by the magnitude but not the direction of the fall given that the impact of fuel was neutralised by reduction in diesel and kerosene prices," Jibran Qureishi, an economist at CfC Stanbic Bank, said. "A slight change in food inflation usually has a big impact on overall inflation but we expect it to move up to about 6.5 per cent in the coming months." 
Qureishi said that the Central Bank's Monetary Policy Committee was likely to hold its key lending rate at 11.50 per cent when it meets next week, saying its tightening on July 7 was geared at anchoring inflationary expectations. The government has a target of between 2.5 and 7.5 per cent for inflation. Kenya
